Award.AwardTitle: CNH: Hydrology, Ecology, and Pastoral Societies in the Sahel: Ephemeral and Perennial Water Resources in a Dynamic Coupled System
Award.AbstractNarration:
The grazing lands of the Sahel region of Africa are a vital grazing resource for the people of Africa, providing seasonal grazing for millions of animals. However, the region is subject to frequent droughts and considerable year-to-year uncertainty in availability of both fodder and surface water for cattle. Many small lakes in the region appear during the wet season but dry out during the dry season and, over millennia, human societies in the region responded to the seasonal availability of water for cattle by developing complex, socially-negotiated, long-distance herd-migration routes that organized and formalized access to the grazing resources of the Sahel. Since the droughts of the 1970s and 1980s the coupled hydrology and socioeconomic organization of the Sahel appears to be changing, with increasing drainage into pools that in some places now provide year-round water for cattle. This project will test the hypothesis that these system level changes were triggered by the drought which reduced vegetation cover and allowed increased water flows into pools. At a certain point, some lakes became deep enough to last through the dry season and, in some areas, the historically migratory communities responded by settling permanently near the lakes. A second hypothesis to be tested is that intense grazing activity now maintains a level of degradation and runoff in these watersheds that perpetuates the perennial lake state and permanent settlement. This project explores these complex interactions and feedbacks between climate, vegetation dynamics, landscape hydrology, and the human societies that depend on and manage these systems.

In Africa, the Sahel is a socio-economically vital region, important for livestock production but vulnerable to drought and famine. Increasing our knowledge of coupled human-natural system dynamics in the Sahel, including the processes that lead to rapid transitions in ecosystem and socioeconomic function, is vital to the wellbeing of vulnerable populations. This project will provide outreach to governmental, non-governmental, pastoral and agricultural communities in West Africa, expand university curriculum on coupled human and natural systems, and train graduate and undergraduate students. This project includes a significant international collaboration with researchers in Mali that is supported by funding from Office of International Science and Engineering's Africa, Near East, and South Asia program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Tropical drylands support a great diversity of wild herbivores and livestock where extensive grazing of cattle, sheep and goats is the primary human land use.  In this research we examined coupled social-ecological systems in arid and semi-arid grazing lands, using examples from Sahelian West Africa.  Loss of vegetation cover in the Sahelian region, associated with drought in the 1970s and 1980s, impacted hydrological conditions controlling the size and dry-season duration of temporary rain-fed pools. In some cases, runoff increases have resulted in the transformation of previously seasonal pools into perennial ponds, and the availability of year-round water for livestock appears to have triggered socioeconomic reorganization and permanent settlement in previously seasonally occupied lands.  In our primary example in the Sahel of Northern Mali, local communities, realizing that water was continuously available, settled permanently to form a village with livestock, market gardens and fishing all contributing to livelihoods.  Studies across the wider Sahel indicate that the size and duration of surface water points has generally increased, suggesting that the post-drought changes in ecohydrology are widespread (although permanent settlement has not occurred in every case).

As part of this project we also reexamined the processes of degradation, overgrazing and desertification in the Sahel and how our perceptions are colored by history, politics and scientific theories. Conventional wisdom suggests that desertification is widespread and irreversible in the Sahel. Indeed, the popular image dating back at least 100 years is of sand-dunes ‘marching’ over the grazing lands and encroaching into the agricultural lands to the south.  While numerous authors have pointed out that the marching sand dune image was never consistent with reality and that degradation in the Sahel is neither as widespread nor as irreversible as often thought, scientific and public perceptions of the Sahel still tend to focus on pessimistic and value-laden ideas relating to overgrazing, loss of vegetation cover, soil erosion and desertification.  

The project results lead to two important conclusions: (1) socioeconomic reorganization of subsistence dryland grazing systems can be triggered by climatic, biological and hydrological interactions that determine availability of surface water for livestock. In these systems, livestock grazing can reduce vegetation biomass and thereby increase runoff into shallow lakes and ponds.  Thus alternate social-ecological stable states can occur because the depth and dry-season duration of these ponds provides a critical bottleneck controlling whether livestock can remain in the landscape year-round or only seasonally; and (2) our analysis of desertification in the Sahel showed how the concept has deep roots in the politics of colonialism, enhanced in later decades by influential social and physical science theories and drought. This combination of science and history planted the idea of ‘Sahelian desertification’ firmly in the consciousness of scientists, teachers, politicians, development agencies and the general public.   When viewed from this perspective it is no wonder that the idea of Sahelian desertification has been so pervasive and remains so persistent.  Increasing evidence of vegetation recovery, however, together with changing perceptions of the social and physical processes impacting vegetation, rainfall and pastoralist land use strategies in the Sahel, combine to challenge the paradigm.  We argue that a less dogmatic perspective on land use and drought in the Sahel, free from prior expectation of mismanagement and degradation, is needed to inform management and rural development interventions.

This research contributed to the education and mentoring of four Malian graduate students who completed Master’s theses, and two Master’s students in the United States.  Project results have been disseminated in scientific papers, conference presentations, and classrooms in Africa and the United States, with publications (published and forthcoming) in leading specialist and interdisciplinary journals.
